page.title: 07CROFTING
page.content: In Durness the agricultural land is divided up in small farms known as crofts.Traditionally a crofter kept sheep,cows,horses,chickens and grew oats,barley,potatoes,turnip,cabbage, carrots and grew hay.Crofters today don't follow the traditional ways.Only a very few people still make their own hay and no one grows oats.Potatoes are only grown for domestic use.Most crofters have a full time job as well. Crofts are used almost exclusively for grazing North Country Cheviot sheep. The Crofters Commision is a government organisation elected to look after crofting property.The Grazing Committe is a local committe elected by the crofters to carry out all the important work connected with sales. They look after the distrubution of income from the sale of sheep. They also look after the common grazing.
